title: get back to work before britain goes under
story: This was , more than the five-year average. Half of those , deaths are blamed on coronavirus.We do not know how the other half died, although some will have missed le-saving healthcare because of the ­pandemic.What we do know is that this hideous virus is killing the economy.The Office for Budget Responsibilitywarns a three-month shutdown will slash growth by more than a third, push unemployment up by two million and raise borrowing by an eye-watering  per cent.Lockdown has destroyed Britain’s “jobs miracle”, put paid to a fragile “Brexit bounce” and triggered what could be the worst depression in living memory.“It is important people know there will be hardship ahead,” warned Chancellor Rishi Sunak, an under- statementever there was one.On your one-hour daily exercise break, you can see the tragedy unfolding.Once-thriving restaurants and bars, busy offices and shops and key construction sites are locked and bolted.Behind every door is a personal and economic tragedy.Despite a torrent of taxpayers’ cash unleashed by Mr Sunak, many will never reopen. Some are already bust. Le will never be quite the same again.The Treasury is stumping up billions to pay furloughed full-time workers, help the self-employed and offer Universal Credit to the very large number who slip between the cracks.We are piling shedloads on to our already massive national debt. For many firms and iniduals this is a devastating blow from which they may never recover, financially or mentally.Lives lost from delayed emergency care, alcoholism, drugs and domestic abuse have rocketed.Together with fatalities from other causes — mostly poverty and despair — they could dwarf the toll from the virus.Some children’s le chances will be wrecked by a long break from school or, worse, from being cooped up with violent family members.Those who keep their jobs may be forced into severe pay cuts. Costs will spill down through the generations.Not everyone is suffering.Public sector jobs and pensions are secure, for the time being.Some with savings, decent homes and jobs they can do from home might actually be enjoying Easter with their families at their side.Breadwinners forced to stay in instead of eating out or flying abroad will have spare cash in their pockets at the end of the month. And some will have grabbed Rishi Sunak’s offer of  per cent pay to put their feet up at the taxpayers’ expense.But it all adds up to a crimson bottom line that our children and grandchildren will have to meet over decades to come. Some of it will be paid for in blood.Without cash from tax revenues, how do we meet Sunak’s pledge to fund — “whatever it takes” — our wonderful NHS and its costly new le-saving treatments The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealCan we afford a generous cradle-to-grave welfare state, good schools or the promised infrastructure linking North and South with better roads and railways One day a vaccine will bring this miserable pandemic to an end. But what will remain — and at what cost Downing Street, without its most important figure at the helm, must find a way to save Britain from destitution without being blamed for “putting money before lives”.It is a challenge only a loony Corbynite leftie would wish on their worst enemy.But to govern is to choose.And despite having just escaped his own near-death experience, it is impossible to see it happening without Boris Johnson’s say-so.The PM knows there will be questions to answer once all this is over.They are already coming thick and fast — on testing, NHS capacity and protective equipment for NHS staff.These need to be settled fast — at literally any cost.We will then need an inquiry into the failure of so-called “experts” to see this coming.We will want a detailed explanation from the Public Health England quango which focused costly resources on obesity and ersity, rather than the pandemic they war-gamed four years ago.Why, for instance, were they so slow to allow non-NHS specialists into the fast-accelerating battle against Covid- A gargantuan rise in debt and unemployment. A terrying collapse in tax revenues. A vast Government bailout to save businesses and jobs.It should be a comfort that these same official forecasts also predict a rapid rebound, assuming the lockdown ends and the virus is largely conquered.But eventhat startling optimism — which we struggle to share — is borne out, immense and permanent damage will already have been done. Millions of jobs will have been destroyed, thriving firms bankrupted and a monstrous new debt pile amassed, taking years to pay off. The pain of the austerity era after  will have been a mere taster.It is good at least that Britain now knows this. We hope it sinks in. The public must consider it before it rails against any relaxing of the lockdown in case more Covid victims die.No one wants more lives lost. But the debate is not lives versus money and jobs. Many will also die from the hardships of poverty, unemployment, tax rises and spending cutsthe economy is kept paralysed much longer.The behavioural scientists advising the Government rightly fear that the public will doubt whether the lockdown’s success in protecting the NHS is still worth itthe recession it triggers kills thousands and destroys the health ­service’s funding anyway.We are not there yet. We do not yet knowUK deaths have peaked, though hospital admissions are flattening and the NHS does now look likely to cope.But the crunch point, where a date is set to slowly release Britain from house arrest, cannot wait much longer.Labour will blame the Tories, but all of these pandemic risks were pointed out as far back as  when Labour were in power.Boris, who became Prime Minister only nine months ago, was occupied with other matters until his December landslide.There are some “green shoots”, to quote one of our medical experts.The NHS now has spare capacity. There is no longer a risk of it being overwhelmed.This was one of the key reasons for the draconian crackdown — to avoid an unmanageable “spike” in crisis admissions.That risk has diminished. It leaves headroom for ato work and school.The sooner that begins, the sooner we will see the “rapid bounce back” forecast by the OBR.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: wuhan wet markets coronavirus reopen who green light
story: Shocked Australian PM Scott Morrison has slammed WHO’s unfathomable backing of trade restarting at the original virus epicentre in China, as the worldwide death toll passed ,.Wuhan, in Hubei province, last week celebrated the end of its strictly enforced, months-long lockdown, with China state TV showing its contentious food markets reopening to customers.Australia’s leader told Channel  yesterday that he was “totally puzzled by this decision” to resume trade at the wet markets.Morrison added: “We need to protect the world against potential sources of outbreaks of these types of viruses.“It has happened too many times.”Australias Health Minister Greg Hunt also criticised China’s plans to reopen the markets.He told ABC News: “There is a very real likelihood that this disease arose from a wet market in Wuhan - it’s clear that these are dangerous vectors.“So we might disagree on this issue with some of the international authorities, but our job is to protect Australians.“And I would imagine that, around the world, the vast majority of people would have a similar view.”Their joint condemnation comes as US President Donald Trump halted funding to the World Health Organisation over its handling of the coronavirus pandemic.Trump claimed yesterday that WHO had promoted Chinas disinformation about the virus that likely led to a wider outbreak than otherwise would have happened.The WHO failed in this basic duty and must be held accountable, he said.America is the biggest overall donor to the WHO, contributing more than million in , roughly  per cent of its budget.Morrison said he sympathised with Trumps criticisms of the group, especially its unfathomable support of re-opening Chinas wet markets, where freshly slaughtered, and live, animals are sold.The coronavirus is believed to have emerged from such a market in the city of Wuhan late last year.Morrison told an Australia radio station: But that said, the WHO also as an organisation does a lot of important work including here in our region in the Pacic and we work closely with them.We are not going to throw the baby out of with the bathwater here, but they are also not immune from criticism.Wet markets traditionally sell fresh produce and live animals, such as fish and exotic animals, which are butchered in the open air. They tend to be popular with shoppers who believe the items on sale are cheaper and fresher than in supermarkets.But theyre poorly regulated.Its not known whether the suspected source of the killer bug, the Huanan Seafood Market, has also been reopened.Confusingly, despite WHO apparently giving the green light to Wuhan reopening its wet markets, one of its experts said the organisation wants them closed.In an interview with the BBC, Dr David Nabarro, a WHO special envoy on Covid-, said its advice is to actually shut wet markets.Although the group does not have the capacity to police the world and can only offer advice and guidance, there’s very clear advice from the Food and Agriculture Organisation and WHO.There are real dangers in these kinds of environments.“Seventy-five per cent of emerging infections come from the animal kingdom. It’s partly the markets, but it’s also other places where humans and animals are in close contact, he added.Hes urged people to make absolutely certain that you’re not creating opportunities for viral spread.China’s markets, where wild and often poached animals are packed together, have been described as a breeding ground for disease and an incubator for a multitude of viruses to evolve and jump the species barrier to humans.Nabarros advice comes as China is now facing a new coronavirus flare-up along its remote northern border with Russia, far from the original epicentre of Wuhan, where it has all but declared victory in the battle against the pandemic.The frontier has been sealed and emergency medical units rushed to the area to prevent visitors from bringing the virus back from overseas.According to Chinas official figures, its had more than , coronavirus cases, and , deaths.The city of Wuhan has been accused of playing down the outbreak with some saying the death toll could be ten times higher than claimed.Its been revealed weeks after it became clear the virus was a killer some districts held huge banquets attended by thousands of people.Whistleblowing medics in the city who tried to alert the world to the spiralling crisis were silenced and one doctor reportedly vanished.However, the deadliest consequence of the cover up was that it allowed the exodus of some m people in the weeks before the city was quarantined on January .This helped transport the virus across China and all over the world.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The title: four waves coronavirus europe us africa
story: EUROPE and the US could see up to three more waves of Covid- once the virus takes hold in Africa, a global health expert has warned. Professor Lawrence Gostin, director of the World Health Organisations Center on Public Health and Human Rights, said outbreaks in the developing world could lead to future epidemics even after the current one is brought under control.Covid- has swept across Asia, Europe, and North America in recent months, but is yet to infect signicant numbers of people in Africa or the subcontinent.Fears have been raised about the likely ability of governments and health system in lower-income countries to contain or combat the coming outbreak.Speaking on BBC Radio s Today programme, Professor Gostin said: Covid- is about to march through sub-Saharan Africa and perhaps the Indian subcontinent like an avalanche.Eventhe United States and Europe were to get their Covid epidemics under control,youve got Covid rages in other parts of the world, in this interconnected society we live in, it will come back to Europe and the United States.And in fact I could predict thatit gets out of control in these lower income countries that we will see in the US and Europe a second, and a third wave, and even a fourth wave of Covid.So were truly only as safe as the weakest link in the global chain.The following countries have each recorded fewer than  cases and no more than six deaths: Ethiopia, Gabon, Togo, Congo, Somalia, Liberia, Uganda, Tanzania, Zambia, Guinea-Bissau, Equitorial Guinea, Benin, Libya, Eritrea, Sudan, Mozambique, Chad, Angola, Zimbabwe, Malawi, Namibia, Eswatini, Botswana, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, Sierra Leone, Gambie, Mauritania, Western Sahara, Burundi, São Tomé and Príncipe, and South Sudan.The professor was speaking following a decision by President Trump to withdraw US funding for the WHO over perceived leniency towards China and the Chinese Communist Party.Announcing the decision yesterday, Trump said: Had the WHO done its job to get medical experts into China to objectively assess the situation on the ground and to call out Chinas lack of transparency, the outbreak could have been contained at its source with very little death.This would have saved thousands of lives and avoided worldwide economic damage.Instead, the WHO willingly took Chinas assurances to face value... and defended the actions of the Chinese government.The Chinese government has faced accusations of worsening the spread of Covid- by trying to cover up the outbreak in its early stages, though President Trump has previously defended it.Writing on twitter in January, he said: China has been working very hard to contain the Coronavirus.The United States greatly appreciates their efforts and transparency. It will all work out well.In particular, on behalf of the American People, I want to thank President Xi!Professor Gostin said he was shocked the president had followed through on earlier threats to limit WHO funding, and that the decision could have a devastating impact globally.Its deeply concerning and dismaying that in the middle of a once-in-a-century pandemic, with tens of thousands of people dying across the world, to actually withdraw funding, or at least limit funding, to the World Health Organisation, he said.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Microsoft founder and philanthropist Bill Gates responded to the move by tweeting: Halting funding for the World Health Organisation during a world health crisis is as dangerous as it sounds.Their work is slowing the spread of COVID- andthat work is stopped no other organisation can replace them.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus press conference matt hancock
story: THE UK has become the fth country to record over , coronavirus deaths, joining the USA, France, Spain and Italy.The government stands before the media once again to provide the latest developments on Covid- in their bid to prevent as many deaths as possible.Todays press conference began at around pm.During the week, these briefings have been held between pm and pm, while at the weekend, it is normally between pm and pm.Top ministers and government officials have been providing these updates on a daily basis since March  from  Downing Street.You can watch the governments daily press briefings by live streaming via our YouTube channel.The Suns live blog will also provide text updates from the conference today.Health Secretary Matt Hancock chaired todays meeting, where he spoke on the Governments strategy for helping care home patients and staff.He was joined by Prof Chris Whitty, chief medical officer for England, and Prof Angela McLean, the UK’s deputy chief scientic adviser.Mr Hancock began by thanking everyone staying at home, and said: “Together we are slowing the spread of this virus.”He also paid tribute to Cpt Tom Moore, , who has raised more than has been to protect residents,” he said, adding: “We will do whatever it takes.”Mr Hancock said that “from the start, the government has focused on the need to control infections in care homes”.Now all symptomatic care home residents will be tested, and therell be testing for all workers and their households.Therell also be more PPE for workers, supplied directly by the Royal Mail.“I want to title: coronavirus lockdown june chancellor earlier exit
story: BRITAIN could stay in lockdown until June, but Chancellor Rishi Sunak is pushing to have measures eased by next month to save the economy.Up to two million people could lose their jobs and the UK is looking at the worst economic slump in  years, experts warned yesterday.Whitehall sources told the Daily Mail that Mr Sunak fears Brits have over interpreted the lockdown advice, and believe only designated key workers should be working.They said he wants to strengthen the message that people should be trying to work unless their entire sector has been shut down, or they cannot practise safe social distancing on the job.Mr Sunak will back a three-week extension of the lockdown, expected to be announced tomorrow, but is said to be deeply troubled by the economic impact.Opinions are ided in Cabinet - with other ministers said to be pushing for the lockdown to last until the end of May - or even into June.There are fears that lting it too early would see a terrying second wave.But keeping it shut for too long risks a complete economic meltdown like experts have predicted.As the UK death toll hit ,, the full scale of the Covid- meltdown emerged in government figures which predicted the country’s economy may be slashed by a record  per cent by June.Unemployment could rocket to . million and the deficit may spiral to £billion this year.The figures, produced by the Office for Budget Responsibility, predict a slump not seen since the s.Ministers are worried about the ability of the economy to bounce back from such a rut - and the mounting billions of pounds being paid out to fund wages and support businesses.He said last night those schemes should be in place by the end of the month, leaving just days to apply and get the funds in before Aprils payday.Mr Sunak tried to rebuke rumours there was a split between Cabinet ministers over theof the lockdown last night.He said: Right now the single most important thing we can do for the health of our economy is to protect the health of our people.It is not a case of choosing between economy and public health - common sense tells us that doing so would be self-defeating.One plan was to start easing social distancing measures in early May - after the first bank holiday.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson, Business Secretary Alok Sharma, Trade Secretary Liz Truss and Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey are said to be backing Mr Sunak to open the country back up as soon as possible.One in ten small firms plans to close or sell up, the Federation of Small Businesses has recently warned, while one in five aims to downsize.The Chancellor said yesterday: This is an unprecedented times and unprecedented crisis and that called for an unprecedented economic response.So in that sense, its not surprising to see some of these figures, as it’s unlike anything we’ve dealt with before.Meanwhile, some ministers are pushing for pupils toto the classroom as soon as May , it was reported last night.One cabinet minister told The : “We have got to make sure this economic downturn is V-shaped and not L-shaped.We should be beginning to release the things that can be released - so primary schools should re-open and so should non-essential shops.If you can go into Sainsbury’s to buy non-essential items while observing social distancing rules, why can you not do that in other shops ”They added: “It looks like elderly and vulnerable people are going to be kept in self-isolation for six months rather than three.”Sir Iain Duncan Smith, former leader of the Conservative Party, agreed, saying: “Schools are important because they enable parents to go back to work, particularly primary schools because those are the children who are too young to be left at home alone. Re-opening primary schools is the key to unlocking labour.”Working with the Treasury, Downing Street is said to be planning for a gradual easing of the restrictions on a sector-by-sector basis.Other options on the cards for helping to lt the lockdown could be reopening other shops, sending some back to work, or allowing the young to go out first.Ex-Chancellor Sajid Javid said today: We should be trying to phase out this lockdown as soon as we possibly can, based on that scientic and medical advice.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThis morning new Labour boss Sir Keir Starmer urged ministers to set out their plan for what happens next.The question for Thursday therefore is no longer about whether the lockdown should be extended, but about what the governments position is on how and when it can be eased in due course and on what criteria that decision will be taken, Sir Keir said in a letter to stand-in PM Dominic Raab.Overcoming this crisis requires taking the British public with you, he added.The government needs to be open and transparent... The silent pressures on communities across the country cannot be underestimated.And he added: I think that some of the decisions made in the last few weeks were too slow and didnt learn quickly enough from other countries, lets not repeat that.But a British government source said all decisions would be guided by scientic advice and data.Talk of an exit strategy before we have reached the peak risks confusing the critical message that people need to stay at home in order to protect our NHSand save lives, the source said.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dad of two given zero chance of survial
story: A BRAVE mum who told heartbroken radio listeners her husband had been given no chance of surviving coronavirus has revealed he is showing signs of improvement after  days on a ventilator.Sue Martin, , rushed to hospital with her children to say their goodbyes to diabetic husband Mal, , after his condition rapidly declined.Doctors told Mal’s family was told that despite him being “very healthy” he had zero chance of pulling through.Sue broke listeners hearts on BBC Radio s Today show as she revealed she was given  minutes to say a heartbreaking final goodbye to her husband.But against all odds, Sue and children Hana, , and William, , have now been given hope - as health workers say he may start coming off his ventilator.The mum-of-two, from Cowbridge in the Vale of Glamorgan, said: “Incredibly, nine days after being told that Mal has almost zero chance of survival, and myself and the children going to say our goodbyes, Mal is still with us.It’s now day  on the ventilator and the hospital have said that he is moving into the weaning phase.Weaning from the ventilator and rehabilitation is going to be an extremely long, slow and painful process, and there are no guarantees that it will be successful, but we are prepared for whatever it brings.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealMal became unwell with symptoms of coronavirus on  March and after  days he was taken to hospital in an ambulance.Sue said: He is still not out of the woods and there are no guarantees for the long process ahead, but the fact he’s still with us given the odds is incredible.Mal, chairman for a recruitment firm, and Sue, communications manager at department for transport, got married in September .She said she was so, so grateful to the ICU team and had been overwhelmed with thousands of messages from people around the world.She added: It doesn’t matter how long it takes, we just want him home with us.

title: scientists six new coronavirus bats same family covid 19
story: SIX new viruses from the same family as the killer coronavirus wreaking a deadly path across the world have been found in BATS.Researchers unearthed the coronaviruses while studying bats in Myanmar - the first time these viruses have been detected anywhere in the world, according to Smithsonian scientists.They collected and tested more than  saliva and poo samples from bats in areas where humans are more likely to come into close contact with wildle in Myanmar.Experts estimate that thousands of coronaviruses - many of which have yet to be discovered - are present in the animals, raising fears that these too could spread to humans.Researchers tested and compared the bat samples to known coronaviruses and identied six new coronaviruses for the first time, confirmed Smithsonians National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute.The team also detected a coronavirus that had been found where in Southeast Asia, but never before in Myanmar, according to findings published in PLOS ONE.Coronaviruses have caused widespread disease in humans, including SARS, MERS and most recently the global Covid- pandemic, which started in Wuhan, China.And the broad scientic consensus holds SARS-CoV-, the virus official name, originated in bats.Wildle vet Marc Valitutto, lead author of the study, said: “Viral pandemics remind us how closely human health is connected to the health of wildle and the environment.“Worldwide, humans are interacting with wildle with increasing frequency.So the more we understand about these viruses in animals - what allows them to mutate and how they spread to other species - the better we can reduce their pandemic potential.”According to the authors, the newly discovered coronaviruses in the Myanmar bats are not closely related to SARS, MERS or Covid-. But, future studies are needed to evaluate their potential for spillover to other species to better understand the risks to human health.The authors said their findings highlighted the importance of surveillance for zoonotic diseases - which can transfer from animals to people - as they occur in wildle.Its hoped the results will guide future surveillance of bat populations to better detect potential viral threats to public health, adds the Smithsonian’s Global Health Programme , which discovered the new coronaviruses in Myanmars bats.The programme investigates emerging infectious disease to combat threats to conservation and public health worldwide.GHPs director, Dr Suzan Murray, last month testied on zoonotic disease transmission before the US House Science, Space, and Technology Committee.She warned: The next global pandemic is not a matter of , but when and where. To quickly identy and contain such infections, health and disease must be evaluated across species on a global scale.Dr Murray said that over the last  years, working with partner agencies, we have identied more than , novel wildle-borne viruses,  of which belong to the same family as the Covid- virus.Scientists estimate there are . million unknown viruses, around half of which could infect people, and some lead to new pandemics. As of now, there are no co-ordinated programs to work in high risk regions to identy these unknown viruses, get their genetic sequences into our labs, and identy ways to reduce risk of them emerging.  Our best defence against spreading diseases that make their way into human populations is through research and education. While we cannot stop every disease outbreak, we can reduce their frequency and build the capacity for a rapid global response when they occur, she added.Army General Mark Milley was asked whether he had any evidence that the virus began in a Chinese laboratory and was perhaps released accidentally.Reuters reported on April  that Milley was non-committal at a Pentagon news briefing.China has already dismissed as a conspiracy theory that the virus emerged from a lab.Milley said: Theres a lot of rumour and speculation in a wide iety of media, the blog sites, etc. It should be no surprise to you that weve taken a keen interest in that and weve had a lot of intelligence take a hard look at that.And I would just say, at this point, its inconclusive although the weight of evidence seems to indicate natural. But we dont know for certain.In Beijing, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian alleged on Twitter last month that the US Army might have brought the epidemic to Wuhan.The claim was denounced by the US government and angered President Donald Trump.Americas State Department said at the time that China was seeking to deflect criticism of its role in starting a global pandemic and not telling the world.As far back as February, the Chinese state-backed Wuhan Institute of Virology pushed back against rumours that the virus may have been articially synthesised at one of its laboratories or perhaps got out from there.A team of  scientists published a statement in the Lancet medical journal in February condemning the conspiracy theories.They said such theories do nothing but create fear, rumours and prejudice that jeopardise our global collaboration in the fight against this virus.Scientists from around the world overwhelmingly conclude that this coronavirus originated in wildle, they added.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: doctor coronavirus spreading farts
story: CORONAVIRUS could be spreading through farts, a doctor is warning. One medic claimed people may be passing the deadly disease on to others through omitting bodily gasses - however experts arent so sure.They say the chances of catching Covid- through farting is tiny and that Covid- is mainly transmitted between people through droplets spread from coughing and touching or shaking hands.Australian doctor Andy Tagg pointed out that farting could cause coronavirus after analysing a series of tests take from coronavirus patients earlier this year.He cited tests that revealed the virus was present in the faeces of  per cent of patients with Covid-.And medics have previously warned farts contain tiny poo particles that can spread bacteria.Dr Tagg wrote: “Well, SARS-CoV- can be detected in faeces and has been detected in an asymptomatic inidual up to  days post-exposure.”The doctor added that previous tests have shown farts have the power to spray talcum powder long distances.He added: “Perhaps SARS-CoV- can be spread through the power of parping - we need more evidence.“So remember to wear appropriate PPE at all times and stay safe!”Despite Dr Taggs suggestion, Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and Clinical Director of Patientaccess, revealed it is very unlikely someone would catch coronavirus from someone who has passed wind.She told The Sun Online: The likelihood of someone catching the virus because they were close to someone who farted is really tiny.You are way, way more likely to catch it by being in close contact with someone who coughs or sneezes, or by picking up dropletson your hands when you touch a hard surface.However, Dr Jarvis urged people to maintain good toilet hygiene - given the evidence showing coronavirus can be present in faeces.She added: There have been some reports of coronavirus being present in poo, and of up to one in ten patients developing diarrhoea a day or two before they get other symptoms such as cough and fever.This does underline the importance of being extra-careful about cleaning the bathroomone person has symptoms of coronavirus.Back in , Aussie doctor Karl Kruszelnicki and microbiologist Luke Tennent carried out an experiment to seefarts could spread disease.Dr Tennent asked a colleague to pass wind directly into two Petri dishes from a distance of five centimeters - first while wearing pants, and then without.He discovered that the first Petri dish stayed clean, while the second one sprouted bacteria overnight - but added the bacteria found in the test was not harmful.Earlier this year China’s Center for Disease Control and Prevention announced that pants should be an effective barrier against farts that might carry coronavirus.The health body said that farts are unlikely to transmit the virus provided pants are worn.However, it warned thatthe infected patient was not wearing pants, and they released a large amount of gas, then someone  –they took a close snf at the gas – could be at risk.And at the start of this month, scientists urged people to close the toilet before flushing as they say coronavirus can be spread through aerosolized poo.Due to whats called a toilet plume, fecal or urine matter can be pushed from the toilet into the air and spread onto other surfaces, a study said.It comes as coronavirus cases in the UK yesterday neared ,, with more than , deaths.The best way title: uks coronavirus lockdown too slow
story: Professor Sir David King, who was in the role between  and , said that he didnt know why the country wasnt more prepared.He said experts had produced reports back in  on dealing with pandemic and showing it would spread eventually to the UKs shires.Speaking to LBC earlier, he said: Why we didn’t respond so much sooner once this epidemic broke out in China, I simply don’t know.And I say this because in , we published a report on actions needed to deal with a pandemic and in that report, we showed thatan outbreak occurred of any new virus of this kind, anywhere in the world, within three months, due to air travel, it would be everywhere in the world and that, of course, is what has happened.He said Britain was unprepared for the outbreak and we didnt take action.We didn’t manage this until too late and every day’s delay has resulted in further deaths in the United Kingdom, he said.Sir David said the plan to push ahead with Cheltenham festival with massive crowds shouldnt have happened.And he blames austerity measures to the cutting back on risk management programmes too - which have cost lives.We were much better prepared for better spending for the Environment Agency on that and equally unprepared for pandemics. For me, this is very upsetting because we had set this preparation process in place, as I say, back in .Britains experts claimed they have done the right things at the right time - even though we waited until after countries like Ireland had began to lock down.The UK is on course for as many deaths as Italy at the moment, as the numbers continue to add up.Ministers think Britain is still some days away from the peak.They are set to extend the lockdown tomorrow after a COBRA meeting to discuss the latest evidence of how the lockdown has worked.Its expected that the shutdown will continue into May - and possibly June.A gradual approach to getting back to normal is expected, rather than reversing all the measures in one go.But the chancellor is keen to re-open parts of the economy to avoid a complete meltdown.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal Now ministers need to massively ramp up measures, Sir David argued today.Until we get testing done on a very much wider scale, we’re not going to begin to manage this, he said,I think it has been taking the eye of the ball, hoping that it would somehow blow away and we are acting too late.A No spokesperson said this afternoon: We believe that we took the right decisions at the right point in time.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: haunting photos worlds largest underwater graveyard ww2
story: Gary Bernnand from Perth, Australia photographed some of the two-hundred-thousand tonnes of shipping that as left to rot after World War .The superb shots show the brutal realities of overseas war from Operation Hailstone in February .The attack, which took place between - February, was a massive US Navy air and surface attack against the Imperial Japanese Navy.Chuuk Lagoon, formally known as Truk Lagoon, was attacked by the US as the area was believed to be a stronghold of the Japanese Navy.More than , Japanese soldiers died during the operation while only  Americans lost their lives.Images show the remains of Japanese soldiers, whose skulls have turned brown from the three-quarters of a century of decay.Other pictures show the seabed caked with ammunition shells and a propeller plane missing two blades after falling to the bottom of the Pacic Ocean.Approximately  wrecks are believed to be there,  small light cruisers, destroyers, auxiliaries and  merchant ships.It is estimated around  Japanese aircraft were shot down around the island.Plaques were placed underwater in February  on the th anniversary in dedication to the preservation and the respect for the remaining ships as a heritage for the people.Chuuk Lagoon, where the pictures were captured, is a large archipelago with mountainous islands surrounded by small islands on a barrier reef.The site - which was made famous by e legend Jacques Cousteau and visited by director James Cameron who made the iconic deep sea movie Abyss - was snapped by scuba ing instructor and photographer, Gary Brennand.

title: china concealed coronavirus must take responsibility
story: Sir John Sawers said Beijing had hidden the disease when it first surfaced and the World Health Organisation had failed to stand up to them.Sir John told BBC Radio : There is a deep anger in America at what they see as having been inflicted on us all by China, and China is evading a good deal of responsibility for the virus.He said China had failed to deal with COVID- when people first started getting sick in Wuhan.The world could not simply turn its back on China as it grapples with the pandemic, he said.At the same time, we cannot find a way out of this without working with China... The world will not be the same after the virus as it was before.Sir John added: Intelligence is about acquiring information which has been concealed from you by other states and other actors.There was a brief period in December and January when the Chinese were indeed concealing this from the West.He said China was increasingly becoming completely at odds with Western nations and US President Donald Trump should lay the blame at Chinas feet, not the World Health Organisations.It would be better to hold China responsible for those issues than the WHO... heads of UN agencies are wary of offending one of the major powersBut that doesnt excuse the head of the WHO for failing to stand up for the facts, the data, and making the right demands of China.I think the WHO has got serious questions to answer about its performance, but anger should be directed against China rather than the UN agencies.Mr Trump has revoked all US funding for the WHO as America plunges into one of the worst global outbreaks of coronavirus.He said the WHO had given America faulty advice on closing their borders to China.Mr Trump said the health body had blew it and failed to make China deal with the severity of the problem and truthfully report case loads.Chinas official death tolls have been criticised as massively underreported.Wuhan locals claim the real death toll in the city was actually , - ten times the number reported by authorities. One of the Wuhan doctors who first tried to warn the world of what would become a pandemic, was told by authorities he would be punished for telling the truth before he died of the virus.The number of cases of coronavirus in China have been steadily flattening after drastic measures were put in place, sentencing the entire country to their homes.China hadnt reported more than  new cases a day in weeks, but fears over a second wave of infections were sparked after a jump to  new cases in a day. In Wuhan, le has started toto normal, and the now infamous wet markets where the virus is thought to have originated have been given the green light by the WHO to reopen.Former Foreign Secretary Lord William Hague has also warned about becoming too reliant on China.He said at an event last night that the Wests policy towards China was incoherent and ineffective.This crisis reinforces the case for two major pillars to be established for Western policy towards China.The first arises from the fact that China isnt going to play by our rules, and that means we cannot be strategically dependent on China in many respects including technology.The other important pillar arises from the fact that we cant solve global problems without China.. the COVID- crisis is an example of such a dramatic world crisis.We cant be dependent on China, but we cant be without a framework of cooperation with China.Lord Hague said he doubted whether there would be an international inquiry into coronavirus, but that the world should learn to change its reliance on Chinese supply chains.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: breast milk cant prevent coronavirus
story: CLAIMS that breast milk could prevent, even cure, coronavirus are unproven, experts have warned.The theory circulating on social media suggests that breast milk contains Covid- antibodies.But, doctors have since slammed this myth - saying theres no proof that breast milk will prevent you from catching coronavirus.Instead they are urging people to practice good hygiene - and wash your hands often with soap and water, for at least  seconds.Theres no proof that breast milk at all can cure Covid or give you antibodies, Dr Dyan Hes, a paediatrician with New York Citys Gramercy Paediatrics, told CBS News.Theres no data that I know of that has been published yet about it.Similarly, Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and Clinical Director of Patientaccess, warned people not to listen to the droves of coronavirus myths about how to beat the virus.She told The Sun Online: There are hundreds of myths out there about how to protect yourself against Covid-. Most of them are exactly that – myths.There are clear ways you can protect yourself and they are the messages we are giving out constantly – thorough hand washing, using  per cent plus sanitiser gel when soap and water aren’t available and avoiding contact with others as much as possible.Please don’t listen to any other nonsense.The myth about coronavirus and breast milk emerged after people touted its benefits online as a superfood with immune-boosting properties.The Daily Beast reported that milk sellers have seen an increase in buyers looking for human milk to boost their immunity or speed up their recovery during the coronavirus pandemic.While breast milk is good for a babys developing immune system, Dr Hes warned that there is a lack of evidence to support the existence of coronavirus antibodies in breast milk.Theres no proof of that yet, this is all hypothetical, she said.[Breast milk] would be the lowest thing on my list. I think you can take some vitamin C and zincyou want to, but do not buy breast milk to prevent Covid. That is not going to help you.Despite this, there is some research being done on the subject with Dr Rebecca Powell, an infectious disease expert at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, putting out a call on social media for breast milk to test for antibodies and their potential ability to combat the disease.However, the research could take months or years, and Dr Powell explained to VICE thatany potential treatment could be derived, the antibodies would need to be puried and concentrated — not just drunk.The UK Government says there is no clinical evidence so far to indicate that the virus can be transmitted via breast milk - meaning there is no known risk of an infected mother passing it to her child through milk.Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, deputy chief medical officer for England, also said that women shouldnt stop breastfeedingthey show coronavirus symptoms.He said: The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologistshas looked at this for us and concluded that there is no obvious risk associated with breastfeeding.As you know breastfeeding is incredibly important for the baby, its incredibly important for mother and baby bonding.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealOur advice at the moment is that with respect thats an inidual womans choice as to whether she breastfeeds, but our advice is that this is the best thing to do.RCOG say the main risk of breastfeeding is close contact between you and your baby, asyou cough or sneeze, this could contain droplets which are infected with the virus, leading to infection of the baby after birth.They urge mothers to wash their hands before touching their baby, breast pump or bottles and to ry to avoid coughing or sneezing on their baby while feeding at the breast.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Mr Hancock batted away the question from Channel  that followed reports up to , could have died in care homes so far.In tonights Covid- briefing, Mr Hancock was asked: You were late addressing the problems in care homes. Was that because you wanted to prioritise young people  And have people died unnecessarily as a result The Health Secretary snapped back: No, neither of those things is the case.He then refused to give Channel  a follow-up question - unlike every other media outlet.Mr Hancock said one of the first things discovered about coronavirus was that the elderly were badly affected by the disease.He added: Therefore it was clear that, especially for care settings supporting older people - and its also true for care settings that support people of working age - we were going to have to have a particular focus.Prof Angela McLean, the UKs deputy chief scientic adviser, said the UK must try everything we can to make sure new outbreaks do not occur in care homes yet to see cases.The government has come under intense scrutiny over what is happening in care homes after providers said official figures on deaths do not match what they are seeing on the ground.The latest report from the Office for National Statistics said the virus killed  care home residents in England and Wales in the two weeks up to April .But industry figures believe the true count is much higher - potentially , since the outbreak started.Campaigners and MPs warned of an unfolding horror that could end up with tens of thousands of forgotten victims.Meanwhile staff in homes have complained about a lack of protective equipment, while just  of the countrys .million care workers have been tested.Elsewhere in tonights briefing, Englands Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty said the death toll may rise later this week, but that he believes the UK is probably reaching the peak of the outbreak.Labour Leader Keir Starmer has put pressure on the government to publish their lockdown exit strategy, saying people need to see light at the end of the tunnel.It comes as a further  hospital deaths were announced in the UK, bringing the total to ,. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: charles ingram where is he now
story: The ex-Army Major swindled the show with the help of his we Diana and a coughing accomplice, Tecwen Whittock.Born in Shardlow, Derbyshire, in , Ingram obtained a degree in civil engineering and a Masters in corporate management before joining the Army in .He became an officer with the Royal Engineers and rose to the rank of Major in .Ingram served in Bosnia for six months on Nato peacekeeping duties.He was forced to resign from the Army in August  following his court case.Diana Ingram married Charles in .The couple met while she was training to be a teacher at Barry College in South Wales, going onto have three children.She had already appeared on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire  prior to her husbands appearances, winning £, - the same as her brother Adrian Pollock also won.In , Major Charles Ingram answered  questions correctly to sensationally scoop the jackpot on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire A court ruled he had answered the questions through help from fellow contestant Tecwen Whittock, who coughed to alert him to the right answers.Ingrams we was also said to be involved.Whittock, a college lecturer from Cardf, was waiting in the fastest finger first group when the controversy erupted.A few days after the show, Ingram received a message to call Paul Smith, the boss of the company which made the show.Mr Smith said there were irregularities during the taping of the show and it would not be aired.Police had also been contacted.It was suggested Whittock had been coughing loudly to indicate the right answer, and blew his nose loudly when the major was about to give a wrong answer.Pagers and mobile phones had been used to help, it was claimed.The  Southwark Crown Court trial lasted four weeks and heard evidence from Ingram claiming the video tape of the show was unfairly manipulated.He insisted he didnt notice the coughing but  coughs were recorded during the second night of the show -  from the ten Fastest Finger First contestants, with  of these signicant.Prosecutors said these coughs were from Whittock, who claimed to have suffered a persistent cough for his entire le.All three were convicted of procuring the execution of a valuable security by deception on April , .Both Diana and Charles were given an  month prison sentence suspended for two years, while Whittock received a  month sentence suspended for two years.After he was sentenced, the Army Board forced Ingram to resign as major after  years of service.Despite this, he went on to remain a TV personality and made several appearances on competition reality shows.He took part in The Weakest Link with his we Diane, while he also competed in The Game alongside former Liberty X singer Kevin Simm.Charles starred in Channel s We Swap, where he swapped his we for Jade Goody.It emerged in  that Ingram paid only £, of the £, fine he was given in  — despite his court case costing the taxpayer more than £million.He retreated to his home in Westbury, Wilts, selling jewellery made by Diana on a market stall.In October , The Sun revealed he was flogging homemade brooches for £ and necklaces for up to £.The Sun tracked down the cheat and found him loading up his belongings into a van to move to a flat on a remote farm.He decided to sell his £, country home after the scandal turned him into a recluse.Charles was last spotted selling jewellery in a Christmas market stall in Bath in , he had declared himself as bankrupt for the fourth time just months before.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: debenhams uk store closures latest
story: Read on to find out which branches are set to close, and why.Debenhams revealed in April  that it was continuing with plans set before it went into administration to close  stores in .As a result of falling into administration again in April , it also decided to axe all  of its shops in Ireland.It had previously closed  stores in January , including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.Weve asked Debenhams how many stores its closed in total over the past few years and well update this story as soon as we get a response.Debenhams told us the exact locations of the  stores set to close next year are still to be determined.It currently has  shops remaining.Debenhams went into administration in April .Its the second time the department store chain has gone bust in a year and also follows a company voluntary arrangement- a type of insolvency process.Debenhams has appointed business advisory firm FRP Advisory to oversee the process.The -year-old retailer last title: british negotiators rule out extending
story: NewsBritish negotiators rule out extending the Brexit transition with the EU againThe two sides have been unable to hold face-to-face meetings with counterparts since the outbreak began and instead are working over videolinkShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritish negotiators again ruled out extending the Brexit transition with the EU.UK ministers and officials have come under mounting pressure to delay the deadline for striking a deal with Brussels as the world battles coronavirus.They have been unable to hold face-to-face meetings with counterparts since the outbreak began. While Britain formally left the EU on January , we immediately entered an -month period where the relationship with the EU remains largely unchanged. Teams have until December  to agree a pact on the new relationship – and either side can walk away from talks in June. British chief negotiator David Frost told the EUaposs Michel Barnier the UK would not request an extension to the December cut-off. During what both sides described as a “constructive meeting” held via video link, officials “took stock of the technical work that has taken place since the first negotiating round on the basis of the legal texts exchanged by both sides,” a statement said. It added: “While this work has been useful to identy all major areas of ergence and convergence, the two sides agreed on the need to organise further negotiating rounds in order to make real, tangible progress in the negotiations by June.” Week-long talks over video calls will take place starting on Monday, followed by another round beginning on May  and a final set starting on June .Acting Lib Dem leader Sir Ed Davey said: “To press ahead with Brexit on the previous timetable – already recklessly fast – is just irresponsible and shows a fundamental disregard for the UKaposs national interest.The Government must stop putting ideology before all , including lives, and start working pragmatically with our European neighbours – some of whom the Government could clearly learn lessons from.

title: coronavirus blanket not resuscitate agreements
story: NewsCoronavirus: Blanket Do Not Resuscitate agreements to be banned to protect elderlyMatt Hancock will try and tackle the growing backlash against the treatment of care home residents by promising a "right to say goodbye" so that families can pay a final visit to loved ones who are dying from coronavirusShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThere is growing criticism of the treatment of the elderly in care homes " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Health Secretary is set to ban the use of “blanket” Do Not Resuscitate agreements to protect elederly people from being abandoned to die from coronavirus.Matt Hancock has told the Care Quality Commission to tell care homes to tear up any agreements that would stop residents getting access to full healthcarethey choose it. Some families report having to sign DNR agreements meaning thattheir relative became severely ill with coronavirus there would be no attempt to revive them from heart or respiratory failure. Mr Hancock is also announcing guidance giving relatives the chance to pay a final visit to to elderly family members who are terminally ill with covid- to give people the “right to say goodbye”. The government has also confirmed that care home residents and staff with symptoms of coronavirus are to be tested as the government faces a backlash over its handling of the growing crisis. Staff have complained about being short of personal protection equipment . Covid- has been identied in , care homes in England, forcing thousands of elderly residents to be kept in isolation in their rooms with no visits. Data from the Office for National Statistics showed  deaths linked to Covid- in care homes between January and April  — but unofficial estimates put the true figure far higher. The changes, which are expected to be announced at the daily press conference, are part of  a four-part strategy to boost confidence in the treatment of elderly people. Staff at homes have complained about being short of personal protection equipment , such as respirator grade masks and a lack of testing. Many families have been sent letters from GPs asking them to give consent to DNR agreements.  Some have been asked to agree in advance that elderly relatives would not be taken to hospital at all, but made as comfortable as possible at the home.  There have also been reports of elderly residents being asked to sign blanket DNR agreements in advance of any infection. Asked about the process the Prime Ministeraposs spokesman said: The healthcare professionals and medical teams, this is something they have been in the lead on rather than ourselves. Iaposm happy to go away and check, but these are really dficult judgements which clinical teams are having to make in extraordinarily challenging circumstances. According to the Evening Standard, Mr Hancock will say that “everyone has a right to say goodbye”. “Wanting to be with someone you love, at the end of their le is one most human instincts there is. Coronavirus has made this much more dficult, and I’ve heard heart-breaking stories of people dying without a loved one nearby. We are sensitively making sure we can limit the risk of infection while giving people’s closest loved ones the chance to properly say goodbye.

story: NewsMatt Hancock denies government set , testing target by mid-AprilThe Health Secretary said that the target had been for the end of the month - which he then increased to ,. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMatt Hancock denies his department set a target of , tests a day by mid-April. Downing Street today revealed that testing capacity now stands at , people a day, but only , tests were carried out in the  hours up to am on Tuesday. The current capacity falls short of the Governmentaposs target to reach , tests a day by Wednesday April . During todayaposs Downing Street press conference Mr Hancock denied that he had set the target, insisting it was originally set for the end of the month. But his own department published a press release on their website saying on  March saying The increased capacity is expected to be ready within  weeks, with highest-priority cases being tested first. It followed an announcement by Mr Hancock in Downing Street on  March. He told the Downing Street press conferencing there is spare capacity in the thousands which gives them the space to increase the number of people eligible. Some , social care staff have already been referred for tests, he said. He said: We committed to , tests by the end of March, which we hit, then we had previously committed to , by the end of April - I increased that goal to ,. We have hit each of the goals that we have set on testing and we have had the capacity continuing to ramp up this month, the demand has been lower over the Easter weekend as staff havenapost wanted to come forward for testing, which is understandable during a long weekend. But the goal is still to reach , by the end of this month.Meanwhile the Government has insisted it is on track to provide all symptomatic care home residents and social care staff with coronavirus testing - despite appearing to miss its own deadline for expansion.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said testing is available right across the NHS and social care for all those who need it as part of the Governmentaposs coronavirus battle plan. Previous guidance said only the first five symptomatic residents in a care home setting needed to be tested to provide confirmation of whether there is an outbreak. As well as current residents and staff who need it, testing will also be provided to all potential residents before they are discharged from hospital, Mr Hancock said. Earlier, experts said the Government must set out how it will rapidly ramp up testing, or risk its pledge being seen as a  promise. The NHS Confederation, which represents organisations across the healthcare sector, said the countryaposs testing capacity is far from where it needs to be. Dr Layla McCay, NHS Confederation director, said: Things are improving but the countryaposs testing capacity is far from where it needs to be to meet the ambition of , a day in just over two weeks. She added: We need absolute clarity from the Government on how this will be achieved in such a short space of time, otherwise it will be viewed as a  promise. The announcement of the rollout follows intense criticism of the Governmentaposs treatment of the social care sector, with claims it has been forgotten as the disease spread.  Increases in the laboratory capacity have opened up the chance for the Government to expand testing to include all care home residents who develop symptoms, the Department of Health and Social Care said. Testing is vital in calculating accurate infection and survival rates. All of the examinations will be PCRtests, which search for the presence of Covid- in a sample. The Care Quality Commission , which is coordinating testing for the care sector, aims to have contacted , care providers by the end of the week. It has already offered , care facilities the opportunity to test their staff. Care providers will then identy workers eligible for testing and refer them to their local testing centre.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Every Thursday at pm, the nation has stood still to clap for carers - the millions of NHS staff and social care workers saving lives from coronavirus. Among those applauding have been Boris Johnson, Dominic Raab and other senior Tory ministers. Because of this, thousands have shared a  story - including on the Mirror - that showed Tory MPs cheering as they blocked a full pay rise for nurses.The story isnapost fake news: Tory MPs did vote down a proper pay rise for nurses in  and they did cheer when the vote was announced. However, itaposs inevitable that some details are lost in translation or over the passage of time. So as a public service, hereaposs what you need to know about the vote. What happened on  June  Tory and DUP MPs defeated a Labour amendment to the  Queenaposs Speech in the House of Commons.Among other things, the amendment aimed to call on the Government to end the public sector pay cap and give the emergency and public services a fair pay rise. However, it was voted down by  votes to .  Tory MPs and  DUP MPs voted against the amendment.In favour were  Labour MPs,  SNP MPs,  Lib Dem MPs,  Plaid Cymru,  Green and  Independent.What was actually blocked     The amendment would not have given nurses and other NHS staff a legally binding pay rise. But it would have sent a powerful and, arguably, a morally binding signal that what they were getting wasnapost enough. At the time of the vote, annual pay rises for NHS staff were still capped at the % a year that theyaposd been since . The amendment also called for a number of other things - see below. So did the government refuse completely to give nurses a pay rise   No. Itaposs completely true that at the time of the vote, the government hadnapost confirmed any extra help for NHS staff other than a % rise every year. Thataposs why MPsapos decision angered many campaigners and NHS workers at the time. But the following year, in summer , the government did eventually confirm NHS staff would get a three-year deal worth between .% and %. Critics of the government would argue that it only changed its course because of years of pressure by Labour, including that vote on  June . Meanwhile, No officials had also made noises about changing policy on the day of the vote, only for their message to be mired in confusion.At pm, a Downing Street spokesman said then-PM Theresa May had heard the message of the election and would listen to pay reviews which have branded the cap unsustainable.But pressed for more detail at pm, the Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman in No then told journalists repeatedly: Our policy has not changed.    It depends who you ask. Labour would say itaposs because they didnapost have NHS staff high enough up their priority list - and werenapost prepared to help them after years of Tory austerity. Tories, on the other hand, accused Labour of using the issue as a political football by lumping in lots of other complaints into the amendment. The amendment couldnapost be split into dferent bits, so had to be either approved or rejected all in one go.Then-Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt said just before the vote: The party of the NHS is not the party that uses it to milk votes it is the party that fights to make it better for patients.And so it was that Tory whips ordered their MPs to vote against the amendment - and it was defeated. Itaposs worth saying the resounding result came despite some Tory MPs wanting to see nurses get a pay rise. One of them, former nurse Maria Caulfield, said nursesapos pay cannot be right and urged a complete rethink. Why did MPs cheer     The simple answer is - because they won. As explained above, the vote came at the end of a torturous day in Westminster where the debate descended into angry party politics. The government, which had a tiny working majority, was relieved to have won by a comfortable margin. So Tory MPs who cheered were gripped by that party-political excitement rather than deliberately putting across a message to NHS workers. But in doing so they created a scene that, in retrospect, appeared insulting and disrespectful to many NHS workers. What was the full text of the amendment  But respectfully regret that the [Queenaposs] Speech fails to end cuts to the police and the fire service commend the response of the emergency services to the recent terrorist attacks and to the Grenfell Tower fire call on the Government to recruit more police officers and fire-fighters and further call on the Government to end the public sector pay cap and give the emergency and public services a fair pay rise.

story: NewsBored mum finds -year-old gold coin worth £, in garden with son’s metal detectorAmanda Johnston from Portsmouth dug up a Henry VII Fine Gold Angel coin, worth around £,, after she decided to alleviate her coronavirus lockdown boredom by taking her sons metal detector to the gardenShareCommentsByNatasha RiglerJoseph WilkesReporter:,  APR NewsAmanda Johnston and her spectacular find " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A bored single mum struck lucky after digging up a -year-old gold coin in her back garden during coronavirus lockdown.Amanda Johnston, , made the incredible discovery with her youngest son George’s metal detector after he lost interest in the device . The hammered coin - a Henry VII Fine Gold Angel - is just mm wide, weighs g and is believed to be worth upwards of £,. Amanda, from Portsmouth, Hants, said: “I was using a little hand trowel and my son’s metal detector when I found the coin. “It’s amazing, I just can’t believe it. It’s quite thin but I realised straight away it could be something special. “I’d like to keep it, but then again,it’s worth £,, it’s tempting to sell it!” Mum-of-two Amanda bought George, , the metal detector for Christmas. But while he quickly lost interest, she found herself hooked on “looking for treasure” at the beach. She then decided to try it in her ft by ft garden, which is located in the ‘Moneyfields’ area of Portsmouth. In times gone by, the area was known for providing bricks to build local houses - not money - but she still gave it a go.  Amanda said: “I was bored and just wanted to seeI could find anything interesting. “To begin with, I just kept finding nails. “It was so annoying but then suddenly my detector started sounding really good.  “I’ve only just finished doing up my garden and am quite meticulous about my lawn, so I really didn’t want to dig it up. “But I went down about eight inches and suddenly saw a glimmer of gold. “I thought, ‘Oh my God…is it  I couldn’t believe what I was seeing’.” Amanda uploaded a photo of her find to Facebook and was soon inundated with comments.She said: “Some people didn’t believe I’d found it in my garden. “But I’m asthmatic and haven’t even stepped out onto the pavement for three weeks.  “It’s really got me wondering what  could be out there.” Amanda’s two sons George and Bradley, , are seriously impressed with their mum’s find. However, they may never get their hands on it.

Corinne and Dave Pruden say they maybe a little bit stupid or naive but they wanted to protect their young children so bought one-way tickets out of the UK. Mrs Pruden, , told Sky News: The other people taking flights were ing home and we felt sort of courageous but perhaps being a little bit stupid or naive - it was quite hard to pigeonhole our actions and emotions and it was quite stressful.
